definition_en: To become less intense or widespread.
example: The storm suddenly abated.

definition_en: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected.
example: The outbreak of violence was an aberration.

definition_en: Regard with disgust and hatred.
example: I abhor discrimination.

definition_en: (of something bad) experienced to the maximum degree.
example: Abject poverty.

definition_en: The act of renouncing or rejecting something.
example: Abnegation of political power.

definition_en: Difficult to understand; obscure.
example: An abstruse philosophical inquiry.

definition_en: Agree to a demand, request, or treaty.
example: The authorities did not accede to the strikers' demands.

definition_en: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions.
example: Business acumen.

definition_en: Warn or reprimand someone firmly.
example: She admonished him for drinking too much.

definition_en: Clever or skillful in using the hands or mind.
example: He was adroit at tax avoidance.

definition_en: Obsequious flattery; excessive admiration or praise.
example: He found it difficult to cope with the adulation of the fans.

definition_en: Difficulties; misfortune.
example: Resilience in the face of adversity.

definition_en: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
example: The pictures give great aesthetic pleasure.

definition_en: Friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
example: An affable and agreeable companion.

definition_en: Brisk and cheerful readiness.
example: She accepted with alacrity.

definition_en: Make (suffering, deficiency, or a problem) less severe.
example: He couldn't prevent her pain, only alleviate it.

definition_en: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
example: Some loved her, some hated her, few were ambivalent.

definition_en: Make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better.
example: The reform did much to ameliorate living standards.

definition_en: (of relations between people) having a spirit of friendliness; without serious disagreement or rancor.
example: There will be an amicable settlement of the dispute.

definition_en: A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists.
example: Everything was as it would have appeared in centuries past apart from one anachronism, a bright yellow construction crane.

definition_en: Deviating from what is standard, normal, or expected.
example: An anomalous situation.

definition_en: A deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion.
example: His fundamental antipathy to capitalism.

definition_en: Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
example: Widespread apathy among students.

definition_en: Pacify or placate (someone) by acceding to their demands.
example: Amendments have been added to appease local pressure groups.

definition_en: Understood by few; mysterious or secret.
example: Modern math and its arcane notation.

definition_en: Involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
example: An arduous journey.

definition_en: (of a person or a person's words) having or showing the ability to speak fluently and coherently.
example: An articulate account of their experiences.

definition_en: Characterized by or suggesting the practice of severe self-discipline and abstention from all forms of indulgence.
example: An ascetic life of prayer, fasting, and manual labor.

definition_en: Make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense.
example: The letter assuaged the fears of most members.

definition_en: Showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks.
example: A series of audacious attacks.

definition_en: Severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance.
example: An austere man, with a rigidly puritanical outlook.

definition_en: The right or condition of self-government.
example: Tatarstan demanded greater autonomy within the Russian Federation.

definition_en: So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
example: Songs with banal, repeated words.

definition_en: Fail to give a true notion or impression of (something); disguise or contradict.
example: His lively, alert manner belied his years.

definition_en: Hostile and aggressive.
example: A belligerent old man.

definition_en: Well meaning and kindly.
example: A benevolent smile.

definition_en: Gentle; kindly.
example: Her face was calm and benign.

definition_en: Support or strengthen; prop up.
example: The fall in interest rates started to bolster confidence.

definition_en: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.
example: Bombastic rhetoric.

definition_en: Concise and exact use of words in writing or speech.
example: The brevity of the report.

definition_en: Relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside and country life.
example: The church is lovely for its bucolic setting.

definition_en: Begin to grow or increase rapidly; flourish.
example: Manufacturers are keen to cash in on the burgeoning demand.

definition_en: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
example: A cacophony of deafening alarm bells.

definition_en: Persuade someone to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery.
example: He hoped to cajole her into selling the house.

definition_en: Showing or having an insensitive and cruel disregard for others.
example: His callous comments about the murder made me shiver.

definition_en: The quality of being open and honest in expression; frankness.
example: A man of refreshing candor.

definition_en: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
example: A capricious and often brutal administration.

definition_en: Reprimand (someone) severely.
example: He was castigated for not setting a good example.

definition_en: Sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.
example: The players were making caustic comments about the refereeing.

definition_en: Express severe disapproval of.
example: A judge was censured in 1983.

definition_en: A person falsely claiming to have a special knowledge or skill; a fraud.
example: A self-confessed con artist and charlatan.

definition_en: Wary and unwilling to take risks.
example: The officials were very circumspect in their statements.

definition_en: Kept secret or done secretively, especially because illicit.
example: She deserved better than these clandestine meetings.

definition_en: Come together and form one mass or whole.
example: The puddles had coalesced into a small stream.

definition_en: Persuade (an unwilling person) to do something by using force or threats.
example: They were coerced into silence.

definition_en: Clear, logical, and convincing.
example: Cogent arguments.

definition_en: Showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements.
example: You can't afford to be complacent about security.

definition_en: Intended or likely to placate or pacify.
example: A conciliatory approach.

definition_en: Be of the same opinion; agree.
example: The authors concurred with the majority.

definition_en: The junction of two rivers, especially rivers of approximately equal width.
example: The confluence of the Blue and White Niles.

definition_en: (of a person) pleasant because of a personality, qualities, or interests that are similar to one's own.
example: His need for some congenial company.

definition_en: An opinion or conclusion formed on the basis of incomplete information.
example: Conjectures about the newcomer were many and varied.

definition_en: Abundant in supply or quantity.
example: She took copious notes.

definition_en: Confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding).
example: The witness had corroborated the boy's account of the attack.

definition_en: Deserving blame.
example: Sometimes you're just as culpable when you watch something as when you actually participate.

definition_en: Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.
example: A cursory glance at the figures.

definition_en: Make (someone) feel intimidated or apprehensive.
example: Some people are daunted by technology.

definition_en: A scarcity or lack of something.
example: There is a dearth of evidence.

definition_en: A sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco.
example: The economic debacle.

definition_en: Make (someone) weak and infirm.
example: He was severely debilitated by a stomach upset.

definition_en: Expose the falseness or hollowness of (a myth, idea, or belief).
example: The magazine that debunks claims of the paranormal.

definition_en: Behavior in keeping with good taste and propriety.
example: You exhibit remarkable modesty and decorum.

definition_en: Humble submission and respect.
example: He addressed her with deference.

definition_en: Describe or portray (something) precisely.
example: The law should delineate and prohibit behavior that is socially abhorrent.

definition_en: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people rather than by using rational argument.
example: A gifted demagogue with particular skill in manipulating the press.

definition_en: Publicly declare to be wrong or evil.
example: The Assembly denounced the use of violence.

definition_en: Express contempt for; ridicule.
example: Critics derided the proposals as clumsy attempts to find a solution.

definition_en: Imitative of the work of another person, and usually disapproved of for that reason.
example: An artist who is not in the slightest bit derivative.

definition_en: A ruler or other person who holds absolute power, typically one who exercises it in a cruel or oppressive way.
example: A benevolent despot.

definition_en: A thing that discourages or is intended to discourage someone from doing something.
example: Cameras are a major deterrent to crime.

definition_en: Intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive.
example: A didactic novel that set out to expose social injustice.

definition_en: Modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence.
example: A diffident youth.

definition_en: A temporary departure from the main subject in speech or writing.
example: Let's return to the main topic after that brief digression.

definition_en: Having or showing care and conscientiousness in one's work or duties.
example: Many caves are located only after a diligent search.

definition_en: A lack of compatibility or similarity between two or more facts.
example: There's a discrepancy between your account and his.

definition_en: The feeling that someone or something is unworthy of one's consideration or respect; contempt.
example: Her upper lip curled in disdain.

definition_en: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less than one really does.
example: This journalist was being somewhat disingenuous as well as cynical.

definition_en: Essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison.
example: They inhabit disparate worlds of thought.

definition_en: Spread (something, especially information) widely.
example: Health authorities should foster good practice by disseminating information.

definition_en: The expression or holding of opinions at variance with those previously, commonly, or officially held.
example: There was no dissent from this view.

definition_en: Inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true.
example: He gives his opinion without trying to be dogmatic.

definition_en: (of an animal) having normal physical functions suspended or slowed down for a period of time; in or as if in a deep sleep.
example: Dormant butterflies.

definition_en: Deceitfulness; double-dealing.
example: The president was accused of duplicity in his dealings with Congress.

definition_en: Cheerful and full of energy.
example: She sounded ebullient and happy.

definition_en: Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
example: Her musical tastes are eclectic.

definition_en: The ability to produce a desired or intended result.
example: There is little information on the efficacy of this treatment.

definition_en: Outstandingly bad; shocking.
example: Egregious abuses of copyright.

definition_en: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing.
example: An eloquent speech.

definition_en: Make (something) clear; explain.
example: Work such as theirs will help to elucidate this matter.

definition_en: Difficult to find, catch, or achieve.
example: Success will become ever more elusive.

definition_en: Match or surpass (a person or achievement), typically by imitation.
example: Lesser men trying to emulate his greatness.

definition_en: Cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken.
example: The heat enervated us all.

definition_en: Cause or give rise to (a feeling, situation, or condition).
example: The issue engendered continuing controversy.

definition_en: A person or thing that is mysterious, puzzling, or difficult to understand.
example: Madeleine was still an enigma to him.

definition_en: Lasting for a very short time.
example: Fashions are ephemeral.

definition_en: Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous.
example: The equivocal nature of her remarks.

definition_en: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
example: Ken could turn any conversation into an erudite discussion.

definition_en: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.
example: Esoteric philosophical debates.

definition_en: A speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly, typically someone who has just died.
example: His good friend delivered a brief eulogy.

definition_en: Make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
example: The exorbitant cost of land in urban areas only exacerbated the problem.

definition_en: Show or declare that (someone) is not guilty of wrongdoing.
example: The article exculpated the mayor.

definition_en: Pressing; demanding.
example: The exigent demands of the music took a toll on her voice.

definition_en: (especially of an official body) absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing, especially after due consideration of the case.
example: The court-martial exonerated me.

definition_en: Stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion or doubt.
example: The speaker's intentions were not made explicit.

definition_en: Invent or concoct (something), typically with deceitful intent.
example: Officers fabricated evidence.

definition_en: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor.
example: A facetious remark.

definition_en: A mistaken belief, especially one based on unsound argument.
example: The notion that the camera never lies is a fallacy.

definition_en: Very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
example: He chooses his words with fastidious care.

definition_en: (of a person) give a display of exaggerated flattery or affection, typically in order to gain favor or advantage.
example: They were fawning over the President.

definition_en: Possible to do easily or conveniently.
example: It is not feasible to put most finds on public display.

definition_en: Intense and passionate feeling.
example: He talked with all the fervor of a new convert.

definition_en: Changing frequently, especially as regards one's loyalties, interests, or affection.
example: Web patrons are a notoriously fickle lot.

definition_en: (of something considered wrong or immoral) conspicuously or obviously offensive.
example: A flagrant violation of the law.

definition_en: Not showing a serious or respectful attitude.
example: A flippant remark.

definition_en: Having a red or flushed complexion.
example: A stout man with a florid face.

definition_en: Instigate or stir up (an undesirable or violent sentiment or course of action).
example: They accused him of fomenting political unrest.

definition_en: Inspiring fear or respect through being impressively large, powerful, intense, or capable.
example: A formidable opponent.

definition_en: Happening by accident or chance rather than design.
example: The similarity between the paintings may not be simply fortuitous.

definition_en: Encourage or promote the development of (something, typically something good).
example: The teacher's task is to foster learning.

definition_en: Not having any serious purpose or value.
example: Rules to stop frivolous lawsuits.

definition_en: Sparing or economical with regard to money or food.
example: He led a remarkably frugal life.

definition_en: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble; secretive.
example: They spent a furtive day together.

definition_en: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
example: Polonius is portrayed as a foolish, garrulous old man.

definition_en: Friendly and cheerful.
example: Waved to them in genial greeting.

definition_en: Habitual greed or excess in eating.
example: She said plumpness was a sign of gluttony.

definition_en: Pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner.
example: A grandiloquent celebration of Spanish glory.

definition_en: (of a person) fond of company; sociable.
example: He was a popular and gregarious man.

definition_en: Sly or cunning intelligence.
example: He used all his guile and guts to free himself from the muddle he was in.

definition_en: Easily persuaded to believe something; credulous.
example: An attempt to persuade a gullible public to spend their money.

definition_en: (of a phrase or idea) lacking significance through having been overused.
example: Hackneyed old sayings.

definition_en: Arrogantly superior and disdainful.
example: A look of haughty disdain.

definition_en: A person who believes that the pursuit of pleasure is the most important thing in life.
example: She was living the life of a committed hedonist.

definition_en: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
example: Germany was united under Prussian hegemony after 1871.

definition_en: Belief or opinion contrary to orthodox religious (especially Christian) doctrine.
example: Huss was burned for heresy.

definition_en: A system or organization in which people or groups are ranked one above the other according to status or authority.
example: The initiative was with those lower down in the hierarchy.

definition_en: Overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style.
example: A histrionic outburst.

definition_en: Of the same kind; alike.
example: Timbermen prefer to deal with homogeneous woods.

definition_en: A person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.
example: An iconoclast who refused to be bound by tradition.

definition_en: Relating to idiocyncrasy; peculiar or individual.
example: She emerged as one of the great, idiosyncratic talents of the nineties.

definition_en: About to happen.
example: They were in imminent danger of being swept away.

definition_en: Unchanging over time or unable to be changed.
example: An immutable fact.

definition_en: (of behavior, performance, or appearance) in accordance with the highest standards of propriety; faultless.
example: A man of impeccable character.

definition_en: Acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
example: Her friend was headstrong and impetuous.

definition_en: Unable to be placated.
example: He was an implacable enemy of Ted's.

definition_en: Implied though not plainly expressed.
example: Comments seen as implicit criticism of the policies.

definition_en: Dispute the truth, validity, or honesty of (a statement or motive); call into question.
example: The father does not impugn her capacity as a good mother.

definition_en: Acting or done without forethought.
example: They had married as young impulsive teenagers.

definition_en: In an initial stage; beginning to happen or develop.
example: He could feel incipient anger building up.

definition_en: (of a person or mental process) intelligently analytical and clear-thinking.
example: She was an incisive critic.

definition_en: Not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings or other aspects of something.
example: The duffel coat looked incongruous with the black dress.

definition_en: Having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned.
example: They seem indifferent to the plight of the poor.

definition_en: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
example: The indigenous peoples of Siberia.

definition_en: Poor; needy.
example: A charity for the relief of indigent artists.

definition_en: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.
example: They were indolent and addicted to a life of pleasure.

definition_en: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.
example: The ineffable natural beauty of the Everglades.

definition_en: Having or showing no skill; clumsy.
example: The inept handling of the threat.

definition_en: Lacking the ability or strength to move.
example: She lay inert in her bed.

definition_en: Impossible to stop or prevent.
example: The seemingly inexorable march of new technology.

definition_en: Well known for some bad quality or deed.
example: An infamous war criminal.

definition_en: Deduce or conclude (information) from evidence and reasoning rather than from explicit statements.
example: From these facts we can infer that the crime was premeditated.

definition_en: (of a person or action) innocent and unsuspecting.
example: He eyed her with wide, ingenuous eyes.

definition_en: Existing in something as a permanent, essential, or characteristic attribute.
example: Any form of mountaineering has its inherent dangers.

definition_en: Tending to obstruct or harm.
example: Actions inimical to our interests.

definition_en: Not harmful or offensive.
example: It was an innocuous question.

definition_en: (of an appetite or desire) impossible to satisfy.
example: An insatiable hunger for success.

definition_en: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects.
example: Sexually transmitted diseases can be insidious and sometimes without symptoms.

definition_en: Ignorant of or uninterested in cultures, ideas, or peoples outside one's own experience.
example: A stubbornly insular farming people.

definition_en: Unable to be touched or grasped; not having physical presence.
example: My assets are all intangible.

definition_en: Endless (often used hyperbolically).
example: We got bogged down in interminable discussions.

definition_en: Hard to control or deal with.
example: Intractable economic problems.

definition_en: Unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something.
example: Her father had tried persuasion, but she was intransigent.

definition_en: Fearless; adventurous (often used for rhetorical or humorous effect).
example: Our intrepid reporter.

definition_en: Overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with.
example: We've been inundated with complaints.

definition_en: Accustom (someone) to something, especially something unpleasant.
example: These children have been inured to violence.

definition_en: Having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change.
example: He was an inveterate gambler.

definition_en: Having or showing a tendency to be easily angered.
example: An irascible, difficult man.

definition_en: Not able to be changed, reversed, or recovered; final.
example: An irrevocable step.

definition_en: Traveling from place to place.
example: Itinerant traders.

definition_en: Special words or expressions that are used by a particular profession or group.
example: Legal jargon.

definition_en: Fond of or characterized by joking; humorous or playful.
example: She sounded in a jocular mood.

definition_en: Having, showing, or done with good judgment or sense.
example: The judicious use of public investment.

definition_en: The fact of two things being seen or placed close together with contrasting effect.
example: The juxtaposition of these two images.

definition_en: Relating to or resulting from motion.
example: Kinetic energy.

definition_en: (of a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words.
example: His laconic reply suggested a lack of interest.

definition_en: A passionate expression of grief or sorrow.
example: His mother's night-long laments for his father.

definition_en: (of a person, manner, or gesture) displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed.
example: They turned with languid movements from back to front.

definition_en: (of a quality or state) existing but not yet developed or manifest; hidden; concealed.
example: Discovering her latent talent for diplomacy.

definition_en: Praise (a person or their achievements) highly.
example: The obituary lauded him as a great statesman.

definition_en: An amount of money or property left to someone in a will.
example: My grandmother died and left me a small legacy.

definition_en: Affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic.
example: I felt tired and a little lethargic.
